q: Optionality in a data model describes:
options: Whether a relationship is required (Mandatory vs Optional)
The choice of which physical database management system to use
The ability of a user to opt-out of data collection
Whether a specific attribute should be indexed for performance
The selection of surrogate keys versus natural keys

q: Data Quality Assessment primarily involves:
options: Measuring the current state of data against defined business requirements
Automatically fixing identified data anomalies in the source system
Deleting records that fail to meet minimum quality thresholds
Estimating the financial cost of poor data quality without empirical data
Ignoring minor data defects to focus on system performance

q: A Data Quality Strategy is best described as:
options: A long-term plan outlining the approach for continuous data quality improvement
A specific software tool purchased to automate data profiling
A centralized database used exclusively for storing data quality metrics
A dedicated Data Steward responsible for manual data entry review
A single SQL query used to identify duplicate customer records

q: Vulnerability Scanning is defined as:
options: The automated, systematic inspection of systems to identify known security weaknesses
The manual attempt by ethical hackers to breach a system's defenses
The physical inspection of server hardware for tampering
The process of writing secure code during the software development lifecycle
The permanent deletion of compromised files from a network drive

q: A Security Audit is:
options: A formal, independent verification that security controls are implemented and functioning correctly
The daily routine of checking employee emails for phishing attempts
The procurement process for purchasing new antivirus software
The hiring of physical security guards for the data center
The routine cleaning and maintenance of office IT equipment

q: Data Stewardship in the context of MDM typically involves:
options: Resolving complex match/merge issues and defining business rules for survivorship
Writing the ETL code required to populate the MDM hub
Installing and configuring the physical servers hosting the MDM software
Selling the organization's master data to third-party vendors
Managing the human resources policies for the IT department

q: Code Cross-Walking is the process of:
options: Mapping and translating reference data codes between disparate systems
Physically transporting backup tapes across different data center locations
Writing custom software code to bypass security firewalls
Deleting obsolete source code from the enterprise repository
Encrypting application source code to protect intellectual property

q: In Business Intelligence, a Dashboard is:
options: A visual display of key performance indicators (KPIs) consolidated on a single screen
A physical component of a server rack used for monitoring temperature
A specific type of relational database table optimized for fast writes
A complex SQL script used to extract data from the operational data store
The administrative interface used by DBAs to manage user permissions

q: A Scorecard differs from a Dashboard primarily because it:
options: Measures performance against specific, predefined strategic targets or goals
Is used exclusively to track the outcomes of sporting events
Calculates the financial creditworthiness of a customer
Is a printed document rather than an interactive digital display
Only displays data that has been fully normalized to 3NF

q: Technical Lineage focuses on:
options: The system-level flow of data, including ETL transformations and physical table mappings
The flow of business definitions and terminology across different departments
The historical record of which users have accessed a specific database
The financial cost associated with storing and processing the data
The strategic roadmap for future data architecture enhancements

q: Business Lineage focuses on:
options: The flow of business meaning, terminology, and conceptual relationships across the enterprise
The physical routing of network cables between different server racks
The tracking of IP addresses used to access the corporate network
The calculation of physical file sizes and storage capacity requirements
The optimization of database indexes for faster query performance

q: Enterprise Content Management (ECM) encompasses:
options: Strategies, methods, and tools used to capture, manage, and preserve unstructured content
The administration of structured relational database management systems (RDBMS)
The configuration and monitoring of enterprise network infrastructure
The procurement and lifecycle management of physical IT hardware
The recruitment and training of data management personnel

q: A Retention Policy defines:
options: The legal and regulatory rules for how long records must be kept and when they should be destroyed
The criteria for hiring and retaining top talent within the data governance team
The formula used to calculate employee bonuses based on data quality metrics
The access control rules determining which users can view sensitive data
The firewall configurations that prevent unauthorized network access

q: Ethical Risk in data management primarily concerns:
options: The risk of causing harm to individuals or society through the misuse of data
The financial risk of exceeding the budget for a new data warehouse project
The security risk of a hacker breaching the corporate firewall
The risk of hardware failure resulting in permanent data loss
The risk of network latency impacting real-time application performance

q: Data Ownership, from an ethical perspective, involves:
options: The rights, duties, and responsibilities regarding the collection and use of personal data
The physical possession of the hard drives where the data is stored
The legal purchase of a software license for a database management system
The requirement for every user to have a unique, complex password
The assignment of a system administrator to manage database backups

q: Descriptive Analytics is designed to answer which question?
options: What happened?
Why did it happen?
What will happen?
How can we make it happen?
Who is responsible?

q: Diagnostic Analytics is designed to answer which question?
options: Why did it happen?
What happened?
What will happen?
How can we make it happen?
Where did it happen?

q: The 'DAMA Wheel' illustrates:
options: The core Knowledge Areas of Data Management and their relationship to Data Governance
The physical components of a magnetic hard disk drive
A gamified approach to training new data stewards
The recommended color palette for designing business intelligence dashboards
A pie chart showing the typical distribution of enterprise data types

q: Data Management is defined as:
options: The development, execution, and supervision of plans, policies, programs, and practices that control data assets
The physical repair and maintenance of computer hardware and servers
The act of writing software code to build new business applications
The installation and configuration of the Windows operating system
The exclusive management of human resources within the IT department

q: Current State Architecture is also known as:
options: The 'As-Is' Architecture
The 'To-Be' Architecture
The 'Was' Architecture
The 'Could-Be' Architecture
The 'Never' Architecture

q: Target State Architecture is also known as:
options: The 'To-Be' Architecture
The 'As-Is' Architecture
The 'Was' Architecture
The 'Maybe' Architecture
The 'Never' Architecture

q: The primary goal of Database Normalization is to:
options: Reduce data redundancy and prevent update anomalies
Increase the physical size of the database to utilize available storage
Slow down the execution of complex analytical queries
Intentionally duplicate data to improve read performance
Confuse unauthorized users by fragmenting the data structure

q: The primary goal of Database Denormalization is to:
options: Improve read performance by reducing the number of required table joins
Save physical storage space on the database server
Reduce data redundancy and improve data integrity
Ensure strict adherence to the Third Normal Form (3NF)
Permanently remove obsolete data from the system

q: A Data Quality Issue Log is used to:
options: Track, monitor, and manage reported data defects through to resolution
Log the timestamps of all user logins to the data warehouse
Record all hardware and software errors generated by the database server
Archive all incoming and outgoing corporate emails
Maintain a record of all customer service phone calls

q: Data Remediation is the process of:
options: Correcting or fixing identified data quality issues
Discovering new data quality issues through profiling
Intentionally ignoring minor data defects to save time
Creating synthetic data issues to test the system's resilience
Generating reports that highlight data quality failures

q: Encryption Key Management involves:
options: The secure generation, storage, distribution, and destruction of cryptographic keys
The intentional loss of keys to prevent data access during a legal dispute
Sharing encryption keys publicly to promote open-source collaboration
Writing encryption keys on paper and storing them in a physical safe
Deleting all encryption keys to improve database performance

q: Social Engineering is a security threat that involves:
options: Manipulating individuals into divulging confidential information or performing actions
Building physical bridges and infrastructure to support data centers
Writing malicious code to exploit software vulnerabilities
Installing unauthorized network devices to intercept traffic
Designing complex database schemas to hide sensitive data

q: The concept of a 'Single Version of the Truth' is:
options: A primary goal of Master Data Management and Data Warehousing
A recognized fallacy that cannot be achieved in modern enterprises
A backup strategy that relies on a single tape drive
The practice of storing all raw data in an unstructured data lake
The use of unstructured data for all business reporting

q: A 'Trusted Source' or 'System of Record' is:
options: A system recognized as the authoritative and verified source for specific data elements
An open-source encyclopedia like Wikipedia used for reference data
Information gathered from unverified industry rumors or social media
A file that has been recently recovered from the recycling bin
Any public website that provides free datasets

q: In dimensional modeling, a Fact Table primarily contains:
options: Numerical measures (metrics) and foreign keys linking to dimension tables
Long, descriptive text fields and qualitative comments
System configuration settings and application parameters
A list of authorized users and their encrypted passwords
System audit logs and error tracking information

q: In dimensional modeling, a Dimension Table primarily contains:
options: Descriptive attributes that provide context for the numerical measures
The core numerical metrics and performance indicators
Empty columns reserved for future data expansion
Highly sensitive trade secrets and intellectual property
Only the primary and foreign keys necessary for table joins

q: Passive Metadata is typically:
options: Created during design-time and used primarily for documentation purposes
Generated at run-time and used to control system behavior
Actively updated by the system without human intervention
Dynamic and constantly changing based on user interactions
Executable code that performs data transformations

q: Active Metadata is typically:
options: Used to drive system behavior and automate processes at run-time
Static documentation that is rarely updated after the system is built
Stored exclusively in offline, paper-based manuals
Printed out and distributed to business users for reference
Slow to access and difficult to integrate with operational systems

q: Version Control in document management is the process of:
options: Tracking and managing changes to documents over time to maintain a history
Permanently deleting older versions of documents to save storage space
Printing physical copies of documents for archival purposes
Scanning paper documents into a digital format using OCR
Emailing documents to a distribution list for review

q: An Audit Trail provides:
options: A chronological log of who accessed or modified data and when the action occurred
A physical walking path designed for security patrols in a data center
A financial record used exclusively for tracking corporate expenses
A paper-based record of all database schema changes
An email distribution list used for security alerts

q: A Fiduciary Duty in the context of data ethics implies:
options: A legal and ethical obligation to act in the best interest of the data subject
A duty to maximize corporate profits regardless of the impact on user privacy
An obligation to write efficient code to reduce computing costs
A duty to attempt to hack into competitor systems to gather intelligence
An obligation to ignore minor data breaches to protect the company's reputation

q: Transparency in data ethics refers to:
options: Openness and clarity about how an organization collects, uses, and shares data
The use of invisible tracking pixels to monitor user behavior
Maintaining strict secrecy regarding the algorithms used for data analysis
Increasing the complexity of privacy policies to protect the company legally
The speed at which data is processed and made available to users

q: Machine Learning is a subset of AI focused on:
options: Systems that learn and improve from data without being explicitly programmed
The manual coding of complex, rule-based expert systems
The manual entry of data into a relational database
The physical repair and maintenance of computer hardware
The configuration of network routers and switches

q: Artificial Intelligence (AI) broadly refers to:
options: The simulation of human intelligence processes by machines, especially computer systems
The biological study of human thought and cognition
The study of animal behavior and intelligence
Theoretical concepts regarding extraterrestrial intelligence
Systems that operate entirely without any form of logic or reasoning

q: Batch Processing involves:
options: Processing large volumes of data in chunks at scheduled intervals
Processing individual data transactions immediately as they occur
The instantaneous transfer of data between two systems
The manual entry of data by a human operator
A process that never executes unless manually triggered by an administrator

q: Real-time Processing involves:
options: The immediate processing of data as soon as it is generated or received
Processing data overnight when system resources are readily available
Processing data on a weekly schedule to generate summary reports
Processing data on a monthly basis for financial reconciliation
A process that never executes unless manually triggered by an administrator

q: A Mission Statement defines:
options: The fundamental purpose and current focus of the organization or program
The detailed technical specifications for a new software application
The visual design and branding guidelines for the corporate logo
The physical address of the corporate headquarters
The contact phone numbers for the IT helpdesk

q: A Vision Statement defines:
options: The desired future state or long-term goal of the organization or program
The current operational status and daily activities of the team
The historical background and founding story of the company
A formal complaint submitted by a customer regarding data privacy
An itemized invoice for data management software licenses

q: System Architecture describes:
options: The structure, components, and relationships of a specific IT system
The architectural design of the physical office building
The urban planning and layout of the city where the data center is located
The high-level business plan and marketing strategy
The logical data model representing business entities

q: A Data Type defines:
options: The format and constraints of a data value (e.g., Integer, VARCHAR, Date)
The total physical storage size allocated for the entire database
The specific business value or meaning of the data
The individual who is designated as the Data Owner
The business name assigned to a specific data element

q: In data quality, Precision refers to:
options: The level of detail or granularity of the data (e.g., number of decimal places)
The degree to which the data accurately reflects the real-world object
The absolute truthfulness of the data regardless of context
The speed at which the data can be retrieved from the database
The physical size of the data file in megabytes

q: Disaster Recovery focuses on:
options: The processes and technologies used to restore IT systems and data after a catastrophic failure
The proactive measures taken to prevent a system failure from occurring
The intentional sabotage of systems to test their resilience
The decision to ignore minor system failures to save money
The permanent deletion of systems that are no longer needed

q: A System of Record is:
options: The authoritative, trusted source system for a specific data element
A secondary backup system used only in the event of a disaster
A temporary cache used to speed up database queries
A user's local laptop where they store downloaded reports
An email inbox where data extracts are frequently sent

q: A Grain Statement in dimensional modeling defines:
options: Exactly what a single row in a fact table represents
The type of food served in the corporate cafeteria
The physical texture of the server hardware
The type of wood used to build the data center desks
The specific metal alloys used in the network cables

q: A Data Dictionary is primarily:
options: A detailed list of data elements, their attributes, and technical specifications
A book used to check the spelling of business terms
A tool used to translate data from one language to another
A directory of employee phone numbers and contact information
A comprehensive encyclopedia of general business knowledge

q: Classification in content management involves:
options: Categorizing content based on its subject matter, sensitivity, or retention requirements
The permanent deletion of content that is no longer needed
The process of writing new content for the corporate website
The act of reading and reviewing content for grammatical errors
The process of selling digital content to external customers

q: A Code of Ethics provides:
options: A set of principles and guidelines governing professional behavior and decision-making
The specific Java code used to implement security controls
A secret cryptographic code used to encrypt sensitive data
A scannable bar code used to track physical IT assets
A postal zip code used to route physical mail

q: Data Visualization is the process of:
options: Creating graphical representations of data to communicate insights clearly
Looking out a window to observe physical phenomena
The act of dreaming or imagining future scenarios
Reading plain text reports to understand business performance
Listening to audio recordings of customer service calls

q: A Stakeholder in data governance is:
options: Any person or group with a vested interest in the outcome of data management activities
A person responsible for holding the physical servers in place
A carpenter who builds the desks for the data governance team
The driver of the delivery truck that transports backup tapes
The pilot of the corporate jet used by the Chief Data Officer

q: An Architectural Blueprint is:
options: A detailed plan or design document outlining the structure of a system
A specific type of blue paint used in data center construction
A physical printout of a database query result
A photograph of the IT team
A rough, hand-drawn sketch of a new software feature
